@pati_gallardo @kode24no Wow, this is so full of gender stereotypes it makes my eyes water.

I don't even know where to start, but the author clearly has no idea of how software projects are run, otherwise he wouldn't dismiss communication as the basis of all we do.

@pati_gallardo @kode24no Research clearly shows that diverse teams are more productive, which he completely doesn't know about, it seems.

It's terrible that @kode24no puts out an clearly biased article like this and does not add an editorial not on it that's its an opinion ...

TL;dr > "If you are born with a vagina, don't bother becoming a programmer."

Middle-aged white dude tries explain, why men should be programmers, and women designers, in Norwegians biggest platform for programmers.

ü§Æ https://t.co/64WqofJch7

While we might see this from a purely technical side (Yay, wearables!) let's consider for a minute that this device was created by women in order to not get killed.

It's shouldn't have to exist. And men are the reason it does. https://t.co/i3bLreLxL0

Teams that do BDD/TDD are much more resilient to technology changes because refactoring / reimplementation becomes a paint-by-numbers task.

Looking forward a few years, we will see more advanced variants of the GPT-3 #AI to be able to fill in the implementation.

This looks like a perfect step-up from the plastic AeroPresses we have which wear out after 2-3 years: https://t.co/1TxfFCepMq https://t.co/zHWBtF2GUD

@malk_zameth What I find attractive is that it's portable (which I also like about the AeroPress), I can take it on vacation, camping, and have the exact same espresso.

@c089 Because it creates much more pressure.

Kinda shocked a new colleague today with the end-to-end testing setup for embedded firmware.

I sometimes blissfully ignore how much parts are involved to ensure continuous quality and just keep solving one small thing after another until the monster is alive.

Also highly recommend a great article by @ChristinGorman: https://t.co/dCfHfryABQ

I think this is what a proper #serverless architecture diagram should look like:
- focus on the scenario / feature (store and retrieve temperature from a device)
- show the flow of data
- show the services involved to enable flow
- link to source code where they are defined. https://t.co/irvusVoFtE

How do you deal with these kinds of yarn updates by @renovatebot: https://t.co/96eql1tYnj

ajv is updated, but ajv-formats depends on it (8.x), however, because we use a lockfile, there are now two ajv versions which makes TypeScript complain.

If fix it by removing and re-adding ajv AND ajv-formats which updates the lockfile.

I am not that familiar with yarn and it's lockfiles, so I wonder if that's expected, if that's the correct fix, and if there is a way to automate the fix?

https://t.co/bMJruH2TWK
https://t.co/uP8URoeBIv

@rarkins @renovatebot No, but I see that this is a renovate config option which will make it run

yarn-deduplicate --strategy fewer

It looks like this tool was made for cases like this.

Thanks, will add it to the config.
@giffesnaffen Nah, not done yet.
@honzamac I don't get how that would help in this case.

@rarkins @renovatebot Added, let's see if that fixes it!

#typescript 4.5 has been released and now it fails to compile code because of TS2589: Type instantiation is excessively deep and possibly infinite.

Some combination of fp-ts, typebox is causing this now.

I am training a junior and outside-in #TDD is a great helper in that because it frames the current task so they can focus on the implementation itself and not spend too much energy on fighting the test runner, or learning ~100 assertion methods.
With reasonably small tasks this gives them the same satisfaction as inside-out TDD and teaches them the value of getting clarity about the task at hand.

@datenreisender @dhh I am working a lot with beginners, both professionally and in private projects. And texts like these, coming from a person with a huge audience have to be seen as having most impact on those that can still be influenced, which are the beginners and less experienced.

It's about being open minded, and fighting a negative, destructive image of oneself in the face of extremely complex technologies.
